ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Biology of reproduction
Reproductive molecular biology, endocrinology, public health, physiology
I learned about hormones that play key roles in pregnancy; growth of babies, fertilization, how to read reproduction papers, etc.
Understanding of the mechanisms behind reproductive anatomy, physiology, etc. Also a brief foray into ethics and current topics

I developed skills in thinking critically about the processes involved in reproduction, puberty, contraception, fertilization, etc. I was able to make a lot of connections between the molecular biology concepts and the real world applications of concepts that will be important for life.
I learned a lot about repro bio and clinical applications
I absolutely loved this this class! I learned so much about reproductive biology
An overview of human reproductive biology across the full length of life from conception to menopause.
Reproductive biology, endocrinology, molecular and cellular
I learned a lot about the human reproductive tracts and associated processes, such as pregnancy, mensturation and menopause.
Reproductive health and science on both a basic scientific level and clinical level

I felt that I gained a far deeper understanding of reproduction, the incredible complexity of these processes, and the scientific researching methods which are responsible for our current knowledge. This course definitely increased my interest in reproductive biology by a significant amount.
It was a great introduction to the reproductive cycle.
I learned about the HPA and HPG axis, how fertilization of mammals occur, the entire process of reproduction from conception to childbirth, and how the gametes are produced.
I learned so much about the reproductive biology of humans. From hormones to ethics we covered a large scope of material.
Developmental biology
I learned much about a variety of topics in reproductive science. My biological knowledge about the reprodcuctive system has grown and I've also learned some useful information for my personal life.
I learned about the human reproductive systems, the specific biology and biochemistry behind it, and also other reproductive health issues.
I learned especially how to combine a large group of different teaching styles across the many different lecturers we had this semester.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Overall very interesting

Strengths - very interesting material! Very well organized course. 
Weakness - very fast paced.
The strengths are that there are resources like TAs to help with exam prep, but the various lecturers sometimes make it difficult to know how to concisely study and the exams are very very specific

Strengths: AWESOME lecturers, great content, very interesting!  The discussion sections were also helpful.  I really loved having multiple choice exams, as it allowed me to engage with the content in a more relaxed manner.  
Weaknesses: Some of the lecturers did not have good powerpoints to study off of later
Strengths include a variety of topics and lecturers that were very interesting and covered a broad range of information, and sections where TA's are really willing to help explain topics.
I enjoyed having each lecture given by an expert in the field. Some lecturers were more engaging than others, but overall I enjoyed going to class and found the material very interesting.
Strengths of this course is how much the professors care about the content. The content is fascinating. Ways to improve the course is less repetition in the content.

I thought the variation in lecturers made the course even more engaging, since every topic was taught by an expert in the field. Having only 3 exams in the course made the workload very easy to manage with other courses. However, I think it would be nice to have another way of getting extra points, like optional extra credit.
I really, really enjoyed this course! I think it would also be even better in person.

Strength: all the topics were interesting and new 

Weakness: some lecturers were better than others. Sometimes professors would try to condense a lot of info into a 50 min class which sometimes made it difficult to understand what was important

The weakness was the fact that each lecture was taught by a different person. While they are experts in their field, they do not communicate well and often material is repetitive or assumes knowledge. 
In addition, this course is only comprised of 3 multiple choice exams. Online and closed book this did not make too much sense to me. 
The strength was the content. I found it easy to study because I was genuinely interested in the material.
Diverse lecture team. Some lectures were very boring.
I liked that we had a variety of lecturers. However, some of the lectures seemed too densely packed with information. Some exam questions were too specific in my opinion.

I appreciated the breadth of the class and how many aspects of reproductive health were covered. Having a different professor for every class for a little jarring and unorganized (but we were warned about it at the beginning of the semester), but was obviously necessary to provide this depth.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: n/a
Giving Midterm 3 open note was great; that made it much more fair to those of us who were not cheating.  That would have been a nice policy to implement sooner.

I liked that the lectures were recorded to re-watch, and I engaged during discussion section where we reviewed scientific papers. There was also time to ask questions at the end of lecture, and some professors asked the students questions during class which I found to be engaging.
Being able to watch lectures later. Useful for exam review
Having the options to go to lecture live was very helpful for engagement, and our virtual sections were also very engaging.
Recorded lectures were nice

The classes during which the professor actually engaged with the students were the most interesting and enjoyable. I really appreciated those lectures. Discussion sections were also really nice ways to engage more deeply with the class.
I thought the virtual lectures were fine. I wish this class had made use of poll everywhere to make it more interactive.
I loved the recorded lectures!
Recorded lectures were useful.

I found it really...strange? that every time class fell on a break day set by Yale College, there was always confusion surrounding whether or not we had class, and it felt like the students' mental health was not being prioritized.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Very interesting lectures
Yes!

YES! I would highly recommend this to any MCDB major, or anyone who wants to take the MCAT.  It is a great way to become more familiar with hormones and steroids, some of which is applicable to MCAT questions!

Speaking as someone not majoring in a natural science: if you truly enjoy biology, then this is an interesting and relatively low-workload way to learn about reproductive biology. Some lectures will feel a little too technical for a non-science major, but the concepts and overarching themes in this course are relevant to everybody.
Yes, this is a great class for a science credit that covers information that is valuable to learn for life in general.
Its a good bio elective

I would because the topics are interesting but it is a little difficult having different lecturers all the time. Everyone has their different style of teaching and its hard to adapt when it changes so frequently.
Yes, a great low work load class
Yes, I would recommend this course to someone looking for an interesting and not too stressful MCDB course. I very much enjoyed it.
Yes I would, but if you are taking this course as a gut it is not a gut.

I would recommend this course to another student. Reproductive biology is very central to our lives, and I started to make many connections with other aspects of my life. I will say that it was not an easy course as there was a lot of material to learn and there were different professors for almost every class.
Yes, if you're interested in reproductive biology and want a low-workload class

I would definitely recommend this course to another student! I felt that I learned a great deal, and I really enjoyed it. I will say that just having the three exams as the only grades makes it a bit hard, but other than that the course was really wonderful.

I would recommend this course to other students looking for a good bio class as well as premed students. For the former group, you dont really need a strong background in bio to understand the content. For the latter group, many of the lecturers were clinicians so it was nice hearing about their work.

I think that if you're interested in learning about how reproduction works and niche topics such as what causes puberty, then go for it! However, I also think that if you aren't personally interested in reproductive biology, the course may eventually become like just another course to get out of the way for a major requirement. The course is very biology and STEM-focused and the tests are all multiple choice and memorization based (as a fair warning for those who may not be used to taking intensive biology courses).
Yes! The content is fascinating!!!
It's a good, low workload class for those interested in learning about reproductive biology, and those that wouldn't mind learning from a different professor each week.
Yes, if they are interested in the sciences.
I would recommend this course for those looking to fulfill certain major requirements. Some of the lectures are too specific to be manageable for non-bio or non-STEM majors.
Yes! I enjoyed this class.

Definitely, if you want a class where you can learn a lot while not having a lot of assessments. If you're a pre-med, then this is a class that is definitely on the medical school level and can give you a head start on reproductive health.
Yes, I very much enjoyed the information I learned this semester.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: some recorded lecture
Live virtual lectures, recorded lectures
Live virtual lecture and live virtual discussion sections.
Section, we went over papers related to course material
live virtual lecture that was also recorded
Guest lecturers
Additional paper discussion section each week
The class was a live virtual lecture whose sessions were recorded for students' later use.
Live virtual lecture and recorded lecture
N/a
This class had live virtual lectures but I chose to watch the recordings instead.
The lectures were live but they were also recorded.
NA
The live virtual lectures were recorded for later playback as well.
The lectures were both live and recorded.
